journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: A reduced basis approach for rapid and reliable computation of structural linear elasticity problems using mixed interpolation of tensorial components element

article-meta.aff: 1State Key Laboratory of Advanced Design and Manufacturing for Vehicle Body, Hunan University, PR China
2College of Mechanical and Vehicle engineering, Hunan University, PR China
3State Key Laboratory of Advanced Design and Manufacturing for Vehicle Body, Hunan University, PR China
4College of Mechanical and Vehicle engineering, Hunan University, PR China

author-notes.corresp: F Lei, State Key Laboratory of Advanced Design and Manufacturing for Vehicle Body, College of Mechanical and Vehicle Engineering, Hunan University, Changsha 410082, PR China. Email: lei_fei@hnu.edu.cn

abstract.p: As the reduced basis method is well used in some other fields to rapidly solve engineer systems, it is adapted to structural computation here. In this article, a reduced basis approach of computing structural linear elasticity problems is proposed to obtain rapid and reliable outputs using mixed interpolation of tensorial components elements. The procedure is as follows. First, structural computation problems based on finite element formulation should be parametrized. As an example, finite element formulation based on a type of element is analyzed and parameters in the formulation are extracted explicitly. Parametrized structural problem is built by assembling finite element formulation of components with parameters. Then, an approximate subspace of lower dimension based on structural outputs within whole parameter domain is constructed by an adaptive procedure. By projecting the parametrized structural problem onto that subspace, it is reduced to a parametrized lower dimension problem, which can be solved rapidly with random given parameters. The procedure is divided into two phases, naming offline and online procedure. Structures in vehicle design problems are employed to verify the feasibility of the procedure and deviation of the accuracy. The results showed that reduced basis approach of structural computation is applicable and efficient.

kwd-group.kwd: mixed interpolation of tensorial components element

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Structure computation of linear elasticity problems are frequently encountered in engineering problems in various fields, such as civil engineering applications and automotive engineering. The behavior of the structure is determined by the characteristic of the materials, the topology of the structures and the size of the parts. In the design phase of a structure, behaviors of a structure with different materials, different topology and different sizes should be tested to provide a full-view of the performance. Usually, it is time consuming to compute the behaviors of a structure with various configurations. To facilitate the design of a structure, various computational methods are invented to accelerate the computation process. Among these methods, reduced basis method (RBM)1,2 is one of the model reduction approaches, which can significantly reduce the computational cost with a reliable error bound.

As a computational procedure, RBM can provide both fast and reliable evaluation of many parametrized systems such as steady incompressible Navier–Stokes equations, fluid flow problems, Boltzmann equation, etc.3–6 A prior convergence theory and a posteriori error bounds7–12 are considered to ensure the accuracy of the method in theory. Liu et al.,13–15 Nguyen16 and Hyunh17 have adopted the method in inverse analysis. The method has shown some significance in these fields; however, only recently little attention has been paid to structural engineering practices. Milani et al.18 have presented some examples of applications in plane strain and plane stress situations.

In this article, RBM is adapted to structural computations based on finite element formulation. Theoretically, RBM is effective only in solving parametrized equations with an asymptotic error bound. Thus, there are several challenges. The first challenge resides in how to obtain a parametrized structural computation problem. As the finite element formulation is a numerical method with parameters in discrete form, it is difficult to obtain explicit parametrized formulation of finite element formulation. In fact, computational structure models obtained by numerical methods, such as finite element methods (FEMs), are expressed in matrixes. Parameters of structures, such as size and material, are expressed numerically in matrix, which means that parameters cannot be changed once the matrixes have been formed. Thus, the basic requirement of reduced basis computation is unsatisfied. The construction of an approximate subspace is another challenge. Usually, the subspace is constructed by an adaptive procedure. In structural computation based on finite element formulation, the procedure should be modified and refined. Reduced parametrized system is obtained by projecting the original parametrized system onto that subspace. Then, the fast computational system is built.

In this article, as examples, structures in vehicle body design are introduced. A formulation of shell element based on mixed interpolation of tensorial components (MITC)19–22 is employed to describe the behaviors of structures. As the MITC4 element is distortion-insensitive and do not contain zero energy modes when the thickness decreases, the thickness of the shell can be chosen as parameters. The article is organized as follows. We first introduce the basic idea of reduced basis approach briefly with its main characters and the procedure of the reduced basis approach in structural computation. Then, parametrization of MITC4 element is carried out to demonstrate the affine decomposition of finite element formulation. The construction process of subspace based on finite element outputs is revealed according to the basic idea of greedy adaptive procedure. Finally, two examples of vehicle structure computation problems are illustrated.

sec.title: Basic idea of reduced basis approach
sec.p: The RBM is a computational procedure that provides both fast and reliable evaluation of an input–output relationship. Several useful insights and new features have been developed and brought in the technique, which improve the feasibility of the method. The main features are the global approximate subspace, the post error estimators and the offline–online computational decompositions. By using these features, we achieve an output computational method, which has both the accuracy of the global numerical simulation model and inexpensive computational cost.

sec.title: Exact form and its affine decomposition
sec.p: Theoretically, engineering analysis requires the prediction of several outputs, such as energies, forces, stresses, strains, etc., as a function of certain inputs related to geometry, physical properties, boundary conditions or loads. The outputs are functional of a field variable ue(μ). ue(μ) satisfies the weak form of parametrized partial differential equation (1)a(ue(μ),v;μ)=f(v),∀v∈Xe,

Here Xe is the appropriate function space, a is continuous bilinear forms, and f(v) is a linear functional associated with the boundary conditions. Generally, it is difficult to find the exact solution ue(μ). We replace ue(μ) with a Galerkin finite element approximation, u(μ). Here u(μ) satisfies (2)a(u(μ),v;μ)=f(v),∀v∈Xn
Here Xn is a standard finite element approximation subspace of dimension n. In order to obtain the sufficient accuracy, n must be large. Thus, the computational effort is expensive.

In fact, for continuous bilinear form of equation, the input–output relationship can be described in another form, called the affine parameter decomposition form. It is the form that the parameters can be expressed as coefficients. That is to say, by using the affine parameter formulation, the equation is decomposed into two parts called parameter function and parameter-independent function. We can rewrite the bilinear form as (3)a(u(μ),v;μ)=∑p=1qΘp(μ)ap(up,v),p=1,…,q where Θp are the parameter-dependent functions and ai() are the parameter-independent forms. The affine parameter decomposition is also applied to f(v) if necessary. (4)f(v)=∑pf=1qfΘpf(μ)fpf(vi), pf=1,…,qf

sec.title: Reduced basis approach
sec.p: It is recognized that although the field variable ue(μ) generally belongs to the infinite-dimensional space Xe associated with the underlying partial differential equation, indeed, it resides on a low-dimensional subspace induced by the parametric dependence. Reduced basis approach is employed based on the fact that the outputs can be obtained in a low-dimensional subspace.
Assuming that we have obtained a low-dimensional global approximation subspace spanned by specified solutions of the equation. (5)WN=span{ζi≡u(μi),1≤i≤N}

And field variable can be approximately expressed in the form of (6)u~(μ)=∑j=1NuRj(μ)ζj where ζj is the n × 1 vector of basis of the approximate subspace, uRj(μ) is the unknown reduce basis coefficient which indicates the weights of contributions of the basis and can be obtained by solving the following set of N equations (7)∑j=1N{∑p=1qΘp(μ)ap(ζj,ζi)}uRj(μ)=∑pf=1qfΘpf(μ)fpf(ζi) where i = 1, … , N. Equation (7) can be expressed in matrix form as (8)K~N(μ)u~N(μ)=F~N(μ) where u~N(μ) is the reduced basis coefficient vector, K~N(μ) and F~N(μ) are obtained by (9)K~N(μ)=∑p=1qΘp(μ)K~Np and (10)F~N(μ)=∑pf=1qfΘpf(μ)F~Npf where K~Np and F~Npf are the parameter-independent parts of reduced matrixes derived by (11)K~Np=ZTK~pZ and (12)F~Npf=ZTF~pf where K~p and F~pf are parameter-independent matrixes derived by affine decomposition, Z is a matrix formed by all the basis of global approximate subspace.

sec.title: Computational procedure
sec.p: There are some important and useful properties of the RBM,23 which can be employed in structural computation.

It is recognized that the strain energy of the structural RBM is a lower bound to that of the finite element solution. As the lower bound of finite element solution is the lower bound of the exact solution of PDEs, the output of structural RBM has a lower bound. The proof of this property is based on the symmetry and coercivity of the bilinear formulation and can be found in Nguyen,16 and Hyunh.17

Another property is monotonic convergence. For a sequence of finite element discretizations of a given structure of different dimensions, the reduced basis subspaces can be expected in the corresponding solution space of FEM. Thus, as the dimension of FEM discretizaitons increases, the accuracy of the reduced basis subspace increases. The monotonic convergence is observed.

Generally, the procedure of fast computation contains two major parts, called offline procedure and online procedure. On the offline stage, the explicit parametrized formulation is first derived. Then, N times of finite element analysis are required to construct the reduced basis subspace. The parameter-independent parts of finite element formulation are then reduced by being projected onto the subspace. The reduced parameter-independent parts as well as the parameters are reformed to construct reduced explicit parametrized formulation. Then, on the online stage, the reduced explicit parametrized formulation is employed and the solution of reduced system is solved. The solution of the original system is computed by projecting the reduced solution back to the original space. The procedure is illustrated as follows in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Procedure for structural reduced basis approach.

It is observed that the offline part is devoted to the computation of parameter-independent terms and is performed only once. The online part is devoted to the computation of parameter-dependent terms and is performed while parameter changes. To complete the offline procedure, two techniques are required.
Affine decomposition of the MITC4 element
Construction of the global approximate subspace

sec.title: Affine decomposition of the MITC4 element
Numerical method of MITC4
sec.p: The MITC4 element was introduced to circumvent the shear locking problem in pure displacement-based finite element formulation. The element is based on choosing appropriate strain interpolations and then tying it to the displacements at specific points. To achieve an efficient and reliable element, the pure displacement-based formulation is extended to use a mixed interpolation of transverse displacement, section rotations and transverse shear strains. The interpolation method used for the section curvatures is the same as the displacement-based method, while the interpolation method for the transverse shear strains is mixed. The degrees of freedom are the same as the displacement-based elements. The element has been tested in solving various well-chosen test problems with respect to the convergence and efficiency.

In engineering practice, the thickness of the shell is chosen as the design parameters. The affine decomposition of MITC4 element is illustrated here. The expression of the principle of virtual work is (13)∫AκTCbκdA+∫AγCsγdA=∫AwpdA where the internal bending moments and shear forces are Cbκ and Csγ, respectively. In displacement-based method, the bending strain is given by the curvatures of the element as (14)κ=[∂βx∂x∂βy∂y∂βx∂y+∂βy∂x]

Being different from the traditional method, the transverse shear strain is interpolated directly by (15)γ=[γxzγyz]=[sinβ-sinα-cosβcosα][γrzγsz] where α and β are the angles between the r and x axes, and s and x axes, respectively. And γrz and γsz are the shear tensor components interpolated at the middle points of the edges in each element. For details, please refer to Bathe.24

sec.title: Affine decomposition of MITC4 shell formulation
sec.p: MITC4 shell formulation are obtained by combining the membrane effects and the MITC4 plate formulation described above. We start from element formulation in a local coordinate system. First, taking the membrane effects into consideration, we obtain the stiffness matrix and force vector from the minimization of the total potential energy, given by (16)kem(μ)dem=fe m, deim={uivi}

Here the superscript m stands for the membrane effects, subscript e stands for the elemental terms, kem is known as the element stiffness matrix of membrane effects in the form of (17)kem=∫Ωμ(Bm)TDmBmdΩ where Bm is the strain matrix, Ω is the element domain and Dm is the elasticity matrix, μ is the thickness of the shell element.

In MITC4 plate element, the stiffness matrix is formulated in the way as the pure displacement-based interpolation does. When bending effects are considered, the stiffness matrix and force vector from the minimization of the total potential energy are given by (18)keb(μ)deb=fe b deb={wiθxiθyi}
Here the superscript b stands for the bending effects, keb is known as the element stiffness matrix of bending effects in the form of (19)keb=keb1+keb2
The first term in equation (19) represents the strain energy associated with the bending strain while the second term represents transverse shear strain of MITC4 element.

The stiffness matrix of MITC4 shell element is then obtained by combining these matrixes. For a four-node element, kem is of dimension 8×8 and keb is of dimension 12×12. We express them in the block form as (20)kem=[k11mk12mk13mk14mk21mk22mk23mk24mk31mk32mk33mk34mk41mk42mk43mk44m]

Here kij corresponds to the sub-matrix associate with node i and node j. Each sub-matrix of kem has a dimension of 2×2 corresponding to the two DOFs u and v at each node, while each sub-matrix of keb has a dimension of 3×3 corresponding to the three DOFs w, θx and θy at each node.

For a four-node shell element, the element stiffness matrix is of dimension 24×24. We next expand kem, keb1, keb2 into the formulation of 24×24 dimension with each sub-matrix positioning at locations corresponding to the DOFs and zeros in the rest locations, given as Kem, Keb1, Keb2. Taking the expansion of kem for example, we represent Kem as (22)Kem=[k11m0k12m0k13m0k14m000000000k21m0k22m0k23m0k24m000000000k31m0k32m0k33m0k34m000000000k41m0k42m0k43m0k44m000000000]24×24 where 0 is the sub-matrix with zeros in it.
Then, the element stiffness matrix is (23)Ke=Kem+Keb2︸μ+Keb1︸μ3

The first two items of the right hand side of the equation (23) are the linear functionals of the shell thickness μ and the third item is proportional to the cubic of the shell element thickness. Equation (23) can be written into two parts, as (24)Ke=μKe1+μ3Ke2 where (25)μKe1=Kem+Keb2 and (26)μ3Ke2=Keb1

The matrices of MITC4 shell elements in the local coordinate systems are then transformed to the global coordinate system. The transformation is performed by (27)KeG=TTKeT and (28)FeG=TTfe where KeG and FeG are the element stiffness matrix and force vector in global coordinate system, the superscript G stands for the global coordinate system, T is the transformation matrix for the element which can be obtained from the direction cosines of local coordinate system. The transforming process is (29)KeG=μ(TTKe1T)+μ3(TTKe2T)

Once the stiffness matrices of all elements have been transformed into the same global coordinate system, the assembly of the global stiffness matrix and global force vector are then performed by following the standard finite element procedure. The global stiffness matrix is then represented as (30)K=μK1+μ3K2 where K1 is assembled from TTKe1T of each element, K2 is assembled from TTKe2T of each element. Both K1 and K2 have the same dimension of K.

sec.title: Construction of the global approximate subspace
Requirements of the subspace and adaptive procedure
sec.p: In RBM, the outputs at selected optimal sample set and its subspace need to be created. Researches25,26 have been done to illustrate the availability of an error bound theory to develop a rapid posterior error estimation based on residual calculations. As the subspace is an important aspect of fast computation, a good algorithm for selecting the snapshots and basis function is required.

Adaptive procedure is a standard procedure and usually used to construct the approximate subspace in RBM. The adaptive procedure is employed to select the optimum basis of approximate subspace. The basic idea is represented here. It begins with the first parameter μ1 randomly in a predefined parameter set, denoted as ∑prior. The corresponding finite element solution is u(μ1). Hence the parameter set is SN'=1={μ1}. The subspace is constructed based on the first solution, WN'=1=span{u(μ1)}. We evaluate the errors of subspace over the predefined parameter set ∑prior. We then choose for μ2 the maximum of errors over ∑prior, hence the parameter set becomes SN'=2={μ1,μ2}. The subspace is then WN'=2=span{u(μ1),u(μ2)}. In words, we pick the next candidate in ∑prior where the associated error is the largest. In adaptive procedure, we repeat this process until the error of approximate subspace over ∑prior is less than the predefined error bound.

In structure computation based on FEM, the subspace is constructed from the outputs of finite element solutions. The procedure of adaptive procedure is illustrated in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Process of GAP in structural computation based on FEM.

sec.title: Numerical examples and results
sec.p: The behaviors of vehicle structures subjected to the certain load cases are evaluated in this article. First, the behaviors of a roof structure with three parameters are computed. And then, the behaviors of an engine cabin with four parameters are analyzed. The behaviors of structures are computed both by FEM and proposed method to compare the accuracy of the method. The computational time is also considered.

sec.title: A roof structure computation problem
sec.p:
The stiffness of a vehicle roof is a key indicator of structural requirements. The stiffness of a roof with vertical loads is computed here. The force locations are illustrated in Figure 3. The roof is constrained at four corners which are connected to a vehicle body. Figure 3.
An example of roof structure computation.

In our example, there are five parts in the roof structure. There are two side rails and three transverse beams. The layout of two side rails are symmetric and they share the same properties of materials and structural configurations. The transverse beams in front and rear share the same properties. The transverse beam in the middle has its own properties. Thus, the structure can be divided in to three groups and each group has the same configurations such as material and thickness.

In the reduce basis approach, assuming materials of parts are of the same type and the shape of each part is determined in previous design phase such as styling, thus, only thicknesses of parts change the behavior of the structure.
Recall that there are three parameters in our problem, the parametrized global stiffness matrix is represented as a summation of six parts (32)K=∑i=13μiKi1+∑i=13μi3Ki2, i=1,…,3.
Here μi is the thickness of the ith sub-assembly, Ki1, Ki2 are the parameter-independent parts of the ith sub-assembly stiffness matrix.

sec.title: Greedy adaptive procedure
sec.p: The approximate subspace is constructed from solutions of the problem with selected parameters. Usually, the parameter domain is divided into a set of sample points. By selecting the optimal sample points, outputs which are used to construct the subspace are generated.
According to the engineering requirements, the domain of each parameter is divided into three sample points, that is (33)μi={0.8,1.2,1.6},i=1,2,3

Thus, the number of sample points is 27. Then, greedy adaptive procedure (GAP) is employed to select the optimal sample points. The selected points among 27 sample points are illustrated in Figure 4. Figure 4.
The select points in parameter domain.

sec.title: The deviation of approximate subspace
sec.p: In GAP, the error of each output is computed by (34)ɛ=‖u~-u‖/‖u‖ where ɛ is the relative error, ‖u~-u‖ is the Euclidean distance between approximate solution and FEM solution, and ‖u‖ is the Euclidean length of FEM solution.

The deviation of approximation subspace is then determined based on the relative errors of each sample points. Assuming the approximate subspace is evaluated over m sample points, we obtain m relative errors, denoted as ɛ={ɛ1,…,ɛm}. The deviation of approximate subspace R is (35)R=‖ɛ‖∞=max1≤i≤m‖ɛi‖, i=1,…,m where ɛ={ɛ1,…,ɛm} is made up of relative errors at m test points, ‖·‖∞ is the infinity norm of the vector.

To illustrate the properties of approximate subspace constructed by greedy adaptive procedure, the deviation of subspace with different dimension are recorded and presented in Figure 5. It is observed that the deviation decreases rapidly first and converges to a stable value. After that, the deviation is no longer decreasing while the dimension increasing. That is to say, there is an error bound which is proved theoretically by previous researchers. The values of deviations are listed in Table 1. Figure 5.
The deviation of subspace with different dimension for roof structure.
Table 1.
The deviation of subspace with different dimension for roof structure.
Dimension of subspace Deviation of subspace
1 5.70E − 01
2 1.16E − 01
3 7.55E − 02
4 2.03E − 02
5 1.15E − 02
6 6.33E − 03
7 4.07E − 03
8 3.69E − 03
9 2.78E − 03
10 2.25E − 03
11 2.01E − 03
12 1.96E − 03
13 1.96E − 03
14 1.97E − 03
15 1.97E − 03
16 1.97E − 03
17 1.96E − 03
18 1.96E − 03
19 1.97E − 03
20 1.96E − 03

sec.title: Computational cost of offline procedure
sec.p:
Computational cost of constructing approximate subspace is now considered. The computational time of constructing approximate subspace contains two parts: (1) time of solving finite element equations at sample points and (2) time of constructing the approximate subspace. The time of solving finite element equations can be determined easily. Time of subspace construction consists projection time and adaptive time. The projection of stiffness matrices requires N(N+n) finite element inner product, where N is the dimension of approximate subspace and n is the dimension of finite element space. Due to the adaptive procedure, the total operation count to construct approximate subspace with N dimension is N(N+1)(3n+2N+1)6 inner product. It is clear that the computational time of adaptive procedure is proportional to the cubic of the dimension N. The computational time of constructing the subspace is illustrated in Figure 6. Figure 6.
Computational time for constructing the subspace for roof structure.

sec.title: Online computational cost
sec.p: The reduced system is obtained by projecting the original problem onto the subspace. Thus, the reduced system has the same dimension of subspace. Given a new parameter configuration, the reduced system with new parameters is solved rapidly due to the lower dimension. We report the FORTRAN cputime using an implementation on the AMD 4200+ CPU and 2G RAM personal computer. Since N is less than the dimension of truth finite element approximation space, the use of reduced system to predict the structural behavior is economical. The average time to obtain a FEM solution is 136.6 s while to achieve a rapid prediction for N = 20 is about 0.00354 s.

sec.title: Front compartment structure of a vehicle
Problem statement
sec.p:
We further illustrate the method with a front compartment structure computation. In this example, the structure is divided into four assemblies. And parts in each assembly share the same properties. Four assemblies are wheel cover assembly, front rail assembly, radiator support and bumper assembly. The torsional load case is considered to evaluate the structural stiffness and the forces are illustrated in Figure 7. The structure is constrained in the rear of front rails which bear the major loads of front compartment. Two vertical forces in opposite direction are applied on the front end of rails to create a torque. Each assembly has its own properties such as material and thickness. For instructional purpose, we assume that all parts in each sub-assembly have the same materials. Thus, we have four parameters to represent thicknesses. (36)μ={μ1,μ2,μ3,μ4}, where 0.8≤μi≤1.6, i=1,…,4, is the thickness of shell element, varies in the parameter domain 𝔻μ. Figure 7.
An example of front compartment structural computation.
Recall that there are four parameters in our problem, the parametrized global stiffness matrix is represented as a summation of eight parts: (37)K=∑i=14μiKi1+∑i=14μi3Ki2, i=1,…,4.
Here μi is the thickness of the ith sub-assembly, Ki1, Ki2 are the parameter-independent parts of the ith sub-assembly stiffness matrix.

sec.title: Discussion of offline computation
sec.p: We choose three levels for each parameter as the roof example does to obtain sample points as ‘low’, ‘intermediate’ and ‘high’. Low level represents the lower bound of the parameter domain while high level represents the upper bound. Intermediate level represents the center of parameter domain. Thus, the number of sample points is 81. The subspace is constructed by selecting the outputs at optimal sample points.

Because of the representation limit, the selected sample points are printed in three figures. For a specified value of the specified parameter, we represent the selected points in Figure 8. In our problem, selected points while μ4 = {0.8,1.2,1.6} are expressed. Figure 8.
Selected points by GAP while μ4 = {0.8,1.2,1.6}: (a) selected points while μ4 = 0.8; (b) selected points while μ4 = 1.2; (c) selected points while μ4 = 1.6.

The deviation of the approximate subspace is plotted to demonstrate the convergence of the error bound in Figure 9. We observe that the deviation decreases rapidly first and then becomes stable. The values of deviation are listed in Table 2. Computational time of subspace construction is recorded and plotted in Figure 10. As analyzed before, the computational time is proportional to the cubic of the dimension N. Thus, it is preferred to select the dimension of subspace with a stable deviation and less computational effort. In our problem, the ideal dimension of subspace is 22 according to Table 2. Figure 9.
The deviation of subspace with different dimension for compartment structure.
Figure 10.
Computational time for constructing the subspace for compartment structure.

sec.title: Online computational cost
sec.p: Computational time saving is obvious for the dimension of reduced system is less than the original finite element dimension. In engineering practice, the stiffness matrixes of both original and reduced system are Hermitian positive definite. The standard way to solve the system of equation is by Cholesky factorization. By Cholesky factorization, two triangular systems are obtained and solved. Cholesky factorization requires ∼ 13n3 flops and each triangular solution requires just ∼n2 flops. Thus, the total work is again ∼ 13n3 flops.

In this problem, the total dimension of finite element equation is 31,182 and the dimension of reduced system is 30. Then, the computational effort of finite element solution is (1039.4)3 times more than that of the reduced system theoretically. In practice, however, due to the development of techniques for solving large-scale problems, the computational time saving is significant but not so dramatically. We report the Fortran CPU time using the same computer device. The average time to obtain a FEM solution is 244.9 s while to achieve a rapid prediction for N = 30 is about 0.01195 s.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, we suggest a new technique to rapidly predict the structural behavior based on MITC4 shell elements and RBM. Being different from the past researches, RBM is employed to demonstrate its advantage in structural computation. As the method is not applicable to the structural computation directly, several works have been done to promote the process. First, formulation of MITC4 element has been analyzed and parametrized to obtain an affine decomposition formulation, which is the basic requirement of RBM. Then, finite element solutions of the problem are employed and selected to construct the subspace required. By Galerkin projection of the parametrized finite element discretization, a reduced parametrized system is obtained. The accuracy of the method is analyzed via two examples to prove the theory of astringency suggested by other researchers. The results show that computational time saving is significant compared to the finite element solution time. For structural analysis in engineering practice, the proposed method is preferred. It is also applicable for other elements of structure by changing the finite element formulation.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work is supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 11102066) and the research fund of State Key Laboratory of Advanced Design and Manufacturing for Vehicle Body (Grant No. 51175001).

ack.p: We are sincerely grateful to Prof. Xu HAN (Hunan University, P.R. China) for important suggestions, remarks and insights.
